newsitem.title: USA: West U.S peak, off-peak power price seen narrowing.
newsitem.headline: West U.S peak, off-peak power price seen narrowing.

text.p: The spread between peak and off-peak power prices in the western U.S. will narrow between now and December as nighttime heating demand picks up and daytime cooling loads decrease, market sources said.
"The nights are getting longer and cooler, but on-peak loads are leveling off," said a western Canadian trader.
Peak hours are generally defined as weekday daylight hours, while off-peak periods are at night and weekends.
On Monday, the Bonneville Power Administration raised its next-day offer price for firm off-peak power to $16.00 per megawatt hour (MWh), compared with $13.00 a week earlier.
Over the same period the Portland, Ore.-based federal agency raised prices for heavy load hours by just $1.00 per MWh to $21.00.

After implementing on Tuesday a new pricing structure which separates transmission from generation, the spread between BPA's peak and off-peak prices for Northwest deliveries stood at just $2.50 and at $4.50 for northern California border deliveries.
"What happens is the thermal plants come up and loads come up along with them," explained a Northwest trader.
"The water starts to diminish so there is less pressure to unload (hydroelectric power) into the off-peak market. There is enough load so people are able to shape hydro into on-peak."
The spread in June between BPA's peak and off-peak offers stood at $7.00, down from as wide as $10.00 in January.
"In December the on-peak prices will start to rise again. By then it is cold around the clock," said the Calgary trader.
